column1: By Luciana Lopez
| COCONUT CREEK

column1: COCONUT CREEK
column2: Fla. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton warned her supporters on Tuesday against complacency as opinion polls show her holding a clear lead over Republican rival Donald Trump with two weeks left until the Nov. 8 election.Clinton told voters in Florida
column3: one of the battleground states where the election will likely be decided
column4: that Democrats could not afford to relax.""I hope you will come out and vote because it's going to be a close election. Pay no attention to the polls. Don't forget
column5: don't get complacent
column6: because we've got to turn people out
column7: she told a rally in Coconut Creek
column8: standing in front of a large sign reading: ""Vote Early.""  Trump also campaigned in Florida on Tuesday. He blasted recent spikes in premiums for health insurance under President Barack Obama's Affordable Care Act
column9: known as Obamacare. Trump promised to repeal and replace the healthcare law as soon as he takes office.""This is why we have to drain the swamp and repeal and replace Obamacare immediately
column10: and I'm the only candidate running for president who will do it
column12: the U.S. government said the average premium for insurance plans sold on Healthcare.gov for 2017 rose by 25 percent compared with 2016.But with polls showing Trump trailing Clinton
column13: Trump has asked his campaign to cut back on work identifying candidates for jobs in his future administration and focus instead on bolstering his chances on Nov. 8
column14: according to two people familiar with the campaign's inner workings.

column1: POWELL BACKS CLINTON
An average of national polls on the RealClearPolitics website since mid-October gives Clinton a lead of more than 5 percentage points
column2: as Trump fights off accusations that he groped women and faces heavy criticism for suggesting he might not accept the result of the election if he loses.            Trump denies the accusations of sexual misconduct and says the election is rigged against him
column3: although he has not cited widely accepted evidence to back that up.On Tuesday
column4: Trump told Reuters that Clinton's plan for fixing the Syrian civil war would ""lead to World War Three
column5: because of the potential for conflict with military forces from nuclear-armed Russia.

column1: In an interview focused largely on foreign policy
column2: Trump said defeating Islamic State was a higher priority than persuading Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to step down
column3: playing down a long-held goal of U.S. policy.Clinton has called for the establishment of a no-fly zone and ""safe zones"" on the ground in Syria to protect noncombatants. Her campaign responded in a statement later on Tuesday noting that both Republican and Democratic national security experts had deemed Trump ill-prepared to be commander in chief
column4: and accusing Trump of ""parroting"" Russian President Vladimir Putin and playing on Americans' fears.Colin Powell
column5: who served as Republican President George W. Bush's secretary of state and was chairman of the U.S. military's joint chiefs of staff under his father
column6: Republican President George Bush
column7: said on Tuesday he would vote for Clinton.

column1: The two candidates have sparred in recent days over the U.S.-backed Iraqi military push to take the northern Iraqi city of Mosul from Islamic State
column2: which Trump described as a ""total disaster.""""He's declaring defeat before the battle has even started
column3: Clinton
column4: who was secretary of state during Obama's first term
column5: said on Tuesday.   She urged supporters to participate in early voting
column6: which began this week in Florida.""Nobody should want to wake up on Nov. 9 and wonder whether there was more you could have done
column7: Clinton said.Clinton also appeared on Tuesday at the Univision studio in Doral
column9: on ""El Gordo y La Flaca"" (""The Fat Man and the Skinny Woman"")
column10: a long-running entertainment show aimed at Latinos. The appearance underscored the importance of Latino voters in the battle for Florida's 29 electoral votes.Clinton maintained a commanding lead in the race to secure the 270 Electoral College votes needed to win the White House
column11: according to Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project results released on Saturday. (Additional reporting by Steve Holland in Sanford

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-usa-sanctions-exclusive-idUSKCN12P2GG	Exclusive: U.S. House to vote on Iran Sanctions Act renewal as soon as November	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The Republican leaders of the U.S. House of Representatives plan a vote as soon as mid-November on a 10-year reauthorization of the Iran Sanctions Act
column2: congressional aides told Reuters on Tuesday
column3: setting up a potential showdown with the White House and Senate.The Iran Sanctions Act
column4: or ISA
column5: which expires on Dec. 31
column6: allows trade
column7: energy
column8: defense and banking industry sanctions over Iran's nuclear program and ballistic missile tests. Its fate is one of the major pieces of unfinished business facing lawmakers when they return to Washington on Nov. 14 for the first time after the Nov. 8 elections.U.S. Representative Ed Royce
column9: the Republican chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee
column10: is expected to introduce the 10-year renewal as soon as Congress gets back
column11: aides said.Congressional aides said a ""clean"" renewal
column12: meaning unchanged from the current legislation
column13: was likely to pass the House. Its fate in the Senate was much less certain
column14: and a White House spokesman would not say whether President Barack Obama would sign it into law.Republicans control majorities in both the House and Senate
column15: and every Republican in Congress opposed the international nuclear deal announced in July 2015
column16: in which Iran agreed to curtail its nuclear program in exchange for relief from crippling economic sanctions.Republicans have since tried repeatedly to pass legislation to clamp down on Iran
column17: accusing Obama of being so eager to burnish his foreign policy legacy that he conceded too much to Tehran in the nuclear talks.Some Senate Republicans want more than a clean renewal of the ISA. They are trying to build support for legislation that would renew it but also do more to punish individual Iranians and businesses over the country's ballistic missile tests and what they see as its support for terrorism.

column1: Some senators have also pushed for a law that would eliminate the president's right to waive sanctions for security reasons.IRANIAN FRUSTRATION
Obama's administration had asked Congress to hold off on renewing the ISA
column2: saying it has enough power to reimpose economic sanctions if Iran violates the nuclear agreement even if it expires.

column1: White House spokesman Josh Earnest declined to say how Obama would respond to the bill if it passed both houses of Congress and reached his desk.""I won't prejudge at this point whether or not the president would sign that bill
column2: Earnest told reporters traveling with the president in Los Angeles.""The president and the Treasury Department retain significant sanctions authority that already has been used to impose costs on Iran for their flagrant violation of their international obligations
column3: he said. White House opposition to the bill could generate resistance from Democrats in the Senate
column4: making it more difficult for any legislation to garner the 60 votes needed to move ahead.

column1: Because Republicans hold only 54 seats in the 100-member chamber
column2: they would need Democratic support to move any bill.Renewing the sanctions bill could also increase frustrations in Iran. Iranian officials have been complaining for months that remaining U.S. sanctions have frightened away trade partners and robbed it of too many benefits it was promised under the nuclear deal.A House Foreign Affairs Committee aide said addressing the ISA before it expires is a ""top priority"" for Royce.""The Iran Sanctions Act was enacted to curb Tehran's support for terrorism and its very dangerous weapons proliferation. It should remain in place until the regime stops exporting terror and threatening us and our allies with deadly weapons
column3: Royce said in a statement sent to Reuters.""That's why I'll be introducing a bipartisan
column4: long-term extension of these important sanctions
column5: he said. (Additional reporting by Ayesha Rascoe; Editing by Cynthia Osterman and Lisa Shumaker)"	['Obama'

| LOS ANGELES

LOS ANGELES The Obama administration is evaluating whether an international agreement reached earlier this month to cut back on greenhouse gases used in refrigerators and air conditioners will need approval by the U.S. Senate
column2: the White House said on Tuesday.Nearly 200 countries

column6: which is an amendment to the 1987 Montreal Protocol
column7: would need to be ratified by the U.S. Senate.

column1: The 1987 Montreal Protocol succeeded in phasing out the use of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)
column2: widely used at that time in refrigeration and aerosols.

column1: There has been an ongoing analysis of the agreement to determine precisely what role Congress may have to play in ensuring that the United States can keep the commitments that were made in the context of that agreement

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-noncompetes-idUSKCN12P2YP	White House urges ban on non-compete agreements for many workers	"
By Daniel Wiessner
The Obama administration on Tuesday called on U.S. states to ban agreements prohibiting many workers from moving to their employers' rivals
column2: saying it would lead to a more competitive labor market and faster wage growth. The administration said so-called non-compete agreements interfere with worker mobility and states should consider barring companies from requiring low-wage workers and other employees who are not privy to trade secrets or other special circumstances to sign them.Vice President Joe Biden in a statement said he had heard from a teacher in Nebraska who was barred from taking a summer job selling pet food to earn extra money. Among others
column3: Biden also mentioned a salesman in Connecticut who was laid off and forced to spend his retirement savings because he was prohibited from accepting other sales jobs.""(Workers) can't reach their true potential without freedom to negotiate for a higher wage with a new company
column4: or to find another job after they've been laid off
column5: Biden said.

column1: Nearly every state allows non-compete agreements
column2: and legal battles over their validity are common. Courts in determining whether the agreements are lawful generally focus on the length of time they are in effect
column3: their geographical limits and whether employees had access to trade secrets. The issue drew attention from some lawmakers and advocacy groups in June when the attorney general of Illinois filed a lawsuit claiming non-compete agreements signed by employees of fast-food franchise Jimmy John's were unlawful. The company said it would stop using the agreements in order to settle the case. The Obama administration on Tuesday also urged states to ban non-compete agreements that are not proposed before a job offer or promotion is accepted and said employers should not be able to enforce the agreements when workers are laid off.

column1: The White House said 20 percent of U.S. workers are bound by non-compete agreements
column2: including 14 percent of those earning less than $40
column3: 000 per year. But many businesses have legitimate reasons for requiring workers to sign the agreements
column4: and states should not simply ban them for wide swaths of the work force
column5: Beth Milito
column6: senior legal counsel at the National Federation of Independent Business
column7: said in an interview on Tuesday.

column1: There need to be individualized assessments of the agreements that consider the industry and the geographical location
column2: she said. (Reporting by Daniel Wiessner in Albany
column3: New York; Editing by Tom Brown)"	['Obama']	[]

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-yahoo-nsa-congress-idUSKCN12P2FL	Yahoo scanning order unlikely to be made public: sources	"
By Joseph Menn
column2: Dustin Volz and Mark Hosenball

column1: | WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Obama administration officials briefed key congressional staffers last week about a secret court order to Yahoo Inc (YHOO.O) that prompted it to search all users' incoming emails for a still undisclosed digital signature
column2: but they remain reluctant to discuss the unusual case with a broader audience.Executive branch officials spoke to staff for members of the Senate and House of Representatives committees overseeing intelligence operations and the judiciary
column3: according to people briefed on the events
column4: which followed Reuters' disclosure of the massive search.[nL2N1C601L]But attempts by other members of Congress and civil society groups to learn more about the Yahoo order are unlikely to meet with success anytime soon
column5: because its details remain a sensitive national security matter
column6: U.S. officials told Reuters. Release of any declassified version of the order is unlikely in the foreseeable future
column7: the officials said.The decision to keep details of the order secret comes amid mounting pressure on the U.S. government to be more transparent about its data-collection activities ahead of a congressional deadline next year to reauthorize some foreign intelligence authorities.On Tuesday
column8: more than 30 advocacy groups will send a letter to Director of National Intelligence James Clapper asking for declassification of the Yahoo order that led to the search of emails last year in pursuit of data matching a specific digital symbol.

column1: We believe such a massive scan of the emails of millions of people
column2: particularly if it involves the scanning of email content
column3: could violate (the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act)
column4: the Fourth Amendment
column5: and international human rights law
column6: the coalition wrote in an advance draft of the letter that was shared with Reuters. The Center for Democracy & Technology
column7: the Electronic Frontier Foundation
column9: Human Rights Watch and the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers are among the signatories.The groups say that Title I of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act
column10: under which sources said the order was issued
column11: requires a finding that the target of such a wiretap is probably an agent of a foreign power and that the facility to be tapped is probably going to be used for a transmission. An entire service
column13: has never publicly been considered to be a ""facility"" in such a case: instead
column14: the word usually refers to a phone number or an email account.

column1: The groups also pressed Clapper
column2: who has pledged to be more transparent in the wake of controversial spying revelations
column3: to explain how much authority the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court has to order technical assistance from technology companies. Reuters reported that Yahoo had installed a special program that was hidden inside a Linux kernel module on its mail servers
column4: where security staffers found it.Representative Justin Amash
column5: who does not sit on one of the relevant committees
column6: recently asked that all of Congress be briefed
column7: given the significance of any change in interpreting foreign intelligence laws.

column1: The briefing should involve all members
column2: because all members will within about a year have to vote on a significant part of FISA
column3: said Greg Nojeim
column4: senior counsel at the Center for Democracy & Technology
column5: which circulated Tuesday's letter among free speech and privacy advocates. ""They should know what occurred so that they can decide whether to outlaw it."" Also last week
column6: Yahoo itself asked Clapper to declassify the secret order or at least describe it
column7: so that the company could respond to news reports and criticism that it did not do more to protect its users' communications. The American Civil Liberties Union meanwhile filed a motion in the surveillance court asking that the Yahoo order and other significant ruling going back a decade be unsealed. (Reporting by Joseph Menn in San Francisco and Dustin Volz and Mark Hosenball in Washington; Editing by Andrew Hay and Lisa Shumaker)"	['Obama']	[]
